The catalyst’s structural dynamics under reaction conditions critically determine their performance. We proved this indication by studying Ni nanoparticles supported on Mo2CT x MXene, where the average size during CO2 hydrogenation changed from 12.9 to 3.1 nm. A parallel increase of CO selectivity from 21.1% to 92.6% at 400 °C was observed, while the CO2 conversion rate remained at about 84.0 mmol·gcat –1·h–1. This transformation involved partial removal of Mo2CT x terminal groups, allowing direct interaction between Ni and Mo atoms instead of indirect coupling through -O terminations. The shift from a Ni-O-Mo to a Ni-Mo interaction enhanced electron transfer from Ni to Mo2CT x , strengthening the metal-support interaction and driving Ni nanoparticle dispersion. In-situ mechanistic analysis and kinetic isotope studies revealed that Ni dispersion suppresses the formate and carboxyl pathway, promotes direct CO2 dissociation, and inhibits CO hydrogenation, shifting the primary product from CH4 to CO. These findings provide a strategy for designing highly selective and stable MXene-based catalysts through engineered metal-support interactions. Graphical Abstract The Ni/Mo2CT x catalyst causes the Ni nanoparticles redispersion in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, suppressing the formate pathway and leading to a product selectivity shift from methane to CO. Keywords Mo2CT x MXene CO2 hydrogenation Metal-support interactions Catalytic selectivity Structure evolution 1 Introduction Selective hydrogenation of CO2 represents a pivotal strategy for mitigating carbon emissions, advancing carbon neutrality, and facilitating carbon recycling, thereby fostering a sustainable, green, and low-carbon economy [1,2]. Captured CO2 can be catalytically converted into valuable fuel chemicals like carbon monoxide, methane, and methanol using H2 derived from renewable energy sources. The impact is to curtail emissions from energy-intensive industrial sectors such as chemicals and steel production [3]. Fuels or platform chemicals, produced directly or eventually indirectly, seamlessly integrate with existing value chains of energy-intensive industries like steel manufacturing [4–6]. Given the inherently stable molecular configuration of CO2, the development of highly active and selective catalysts is imperative for efficient CO2 hydrogenation reactions [7,8]. Consequently, elucidating the intricate interplay in CO2 hydrogenation between the selectivity, activity and structural catalysts dynamics becomes essential. Two-dimensional transition metal carbides, known as MXenes, have attracted significant attention as potential catalytic materials and catalyst supports due to their unique properties, including flat metallic surface atom layers, abundant and tunable terminal groups, and intrinsic defect structures [9–11]. Similar to bulk carbides [12], MXenes exhibit peculiar catalytic activity in certain reactions due to the different types of functional groups which are present. For instance, Diao et al. [13] demonstrated that Ti3C2T x can catalyse the dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene to produce styrene, with the –OH terminal group serving as an effective active site. Furthermore, after the removal of terminal groups, Mo2CT x has shown catalytic performance in CO2 hydrogenation and Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [14,15]. In addition to their intrinsic catalytic properties, MXene-based catalyst supports offer abundant anchoring sites and exhibit distinctive metal-support interactions. For example, Zhao et al. [16] reported that Ti vacancies on Ti3C2T x can anchor noble metal single atoms. Leveraging the dissociation activity of Mo2CT x toward N2, Co- and Re-loaded Mo2CT x catalysts has demonstrated excellent performance in ammonia synthesis [17,18]. Despite these promising developments, research on MXenes as thermal catalytic materials remains limited. Critical aspects, such as the nature of metal-support interactions between metals and MXenes and their change during catalytic reactions, deserve more investigation. Catalysts are not static entities under reaction conditions. Rather, they undergo structural dynamics driven by temperature and reaction gas environment, ultimately achieving a structural change that may lead even to a complete deactivation [19,20]. Ostwald ripening serves as a classic illustration of such catalyst in-situ change, exemplified by the Co sintering in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, which leads to deactivation [21]. On the other hand, reverse Ostwald ripening may occur in other catalytic reactions or conditions, with metal nanoparticles (NPs) being changed from larger into smaller ones. For instance, Xiao et al. [22] observed that Cu NPs supported on dealuminated beta zeolite spontaneously modify from an average size of 5.6 to 2.4 nm in the dimethyl oxalate hydrogenation reaction. Zhao et al. [23] reported the change of Pd from NPs to single atoms on the surface of TiO2 in CO2 hydrogenation. Thus, in this case, the in-situ transformation during the catalytic reaction is a way to activate rather than deactivate the catalyst. Not only metals but also supports can undergo in-situ structural changes, even if it is a topic less investigated. An exception is the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) effect, e.g. TiO2 migrates to the Rh NPs surface in CO2 hydrogenation reactions, forming an encapsulating layer [24]. The structural transformation of catalysts under reaction conditions is governed by the intricate multicomponent interaction among the metal, support, and adsorbate, commonly referred to as adsorbate-mediated strong-metal support interaction (A-SMSI). However, the SMSI effect refers to the coverage and, finally, encapsulation of metal NPs by an oxide layer. This effect is a part of the more general phenomenon of in situ chances in a catalyst driven by a reactive atmosphere and metal-support interactions. When carbides serve as supports, the influence of the reaction atmosphere becomes pivotal. Liu and co-workers [25] demonstrated that Au NPs spontaneously dispersed into a monolayer of Au atoms under a CH4/H2 atmosphere. Similarly, Li et al. [26] reported that Pt NPs formed a monolayer coverage on the Mo2TiC2T x surface under an H2 atmosphere, while Pt forms a Pt3Ti alloy with Ti in Ti3C2T x [27]. In addition to the effects of ripening, dispersion, and alloying of metal NPs induced by the reactive atmosphere, supports themselves can transform. For instance, α-MoC undergoes decarbonisation to β-Mo2C at high temperatures under H2 but exhibits higher thermal stability in a CO2/H2 atmosphere [28]. Unlike carbides with uneven O atom distribution on the surface, MXene surfaces are uniformly covered with —O and —OH terminal groups. They will influence the interaction between supported metals and the MXene substrate, including important aspects such as the mechanism of interaction, the charge transfer dynamics, the NP’s shape and size, and the impact of the reactive atmosphere. These considerations are crucial when considering the design of MXene-based catalysts. Here, we reveal the in-situ structural change of Mo2CT x MXene-supported Ni NP catalysts during CO2 hydrogenation reactions. The structural and compositional changes of the catalysts were systematically analysed using electron microscopy and X-ray methods, providing indications of how the interaction between Ni NPs and Mo2CT x drove the catalyst insitu structural dynamics. In-situ reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) and isotope experiments resolved the impact of the competition between the formate pathway and the carbide pathway on the selectivity of CO2 hydrogenation. Our results indicate that controlling the support effect through the reaction atmosphere is an effective means to manipulate the chemical selectivity of metal catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Mo2CTx Mo2CT x (MXene) was synthesised via an HCl etching method. Initially, 2.5 g of Mo2Ga2C and 50 mL of 10% HCl were placed in a 100 mL hydrothermal reactor and reacted at 180 °C for 24 h. The reaction mixture was then filtered and washed to obtain multilayered Mo2CT x . Subsequently, 2.0 g of the multilayered Mo2CT x and 2 mL of 25 wt% tetrapropylammonium hydroxide were dispersed in 20 mL of deionised water and ultrasonicated for 2 h. Following this, 2.0 g of (NH4)2CO3 was added, leading to the precipitation of single-layer Mo2CT x . Finally, the product was filtered, washed, and vacuum-dried to yield Mo2CT x . 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Ni/Mo2CT x catalyst was prepared via an impregnation method. In this process, 0.9517 g of nickel acetate tetrahydrate was dissolved in 100 mL of deionised water, followed by the addition of 2.00 g of Mo2CT x . The mixture was stirred continuously for 6 h, after which the water was removed using rotary evaporation. The resulting material was vacuum-dried at 60 °C overnight and then calcined at 350 °C for 2 h in a tubular furnace under flowing Ar, yielding the Ni/Mo2CT x catalyst. 2.3 Characterization techniques X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were operated on an X’pert-Pro diffractometer (PAN Analytical, Holland) using Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA in the range of 10°–80°. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analyses were carried out on a JEOL 7800F microscope at 3 kV accelerated voltage. High-resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) and bright field scanning transmission electron microscopy (BF-STEM) and energy loss electron spectroscopy (EELS) analyses were carried out by phase-corrected electron microscope (Titan Themis G3 ETEM, Thermo Scientific Company). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a spectrometer equipped with an Al Kα X-ray source at a pass energy of 20 eV (Thermofisher Escalab 250 Xi+). The binding energies were calibrated using the C 1s characteristics of adventitious carbon at 284.8 eV. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm were measured at –196 °C using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 plus sorptometer. The temperature-programmed reaction tests, i.e., (1) CO2-temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) and (2) CO-temperature-programmed desorption (CO-TPD) and (3) H-D exchange experiments, were carried out in a fixed bed reactor with a U-shaped quartz tube (inner diameter 6 mm). The feed and reaction products were monitored by mass spectroscopy (MS, Pfeiffer GSD 320). In-situ DRIFTS was performed using a VERTEX 80 V instrument (Bruker) to analyse the intermediates on the catalyst surface. The catalyst was pre-treated in a fixed-bed reactor, followed by additional treatment in the in-situ DRIFTS reactor for 1 h, and subsequently purged with Ar for 30 min. High-purity H2 and Ar were used throughout the process, and the reacting gas mixture consisted of 5% CO2, 20% H2, and 80% Ar. Spectra were recorded at 30-s intervals by collecting 32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm–1. 2.4 Catalytic performance evaluation The RWGS reaction was evaluated at atmospheric pressure in a quartz tube reactor (d = 8 mm). Before testing, the catalysts (50 mg) were treated in 40 mL min–1 H2 at 350 °C for 1 h to obtain Mo2CT x -R (R indicating after reduction) or further treated at 300, 400, 500 and 600 °C for 2 h in reactant mixture (10 mL·min–1 CO2, 40 mL·min–1 H2 and 5 mL·min–1 N2) to obtain Ni/Mo2CT x -Tk (k = 300, 400, 500 and 600, indicating the pretreatment temperature). The reactant mixture under a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 60000 mL·gcat –1·h–1 was then introduced through a mass-flow controller. The products were analyzed using online gas chromatography (Agilent 7890B) after a 40-min stabilization period at each temperature. CO2 conversion, CO and CH4 selectivity and the specific conversion rate were calculated using the equations below: (1) CO2 conversion (%) = (F CO2,in – F CO2,out)/F CO2,in × 100% (1) CH4 or CO selectivity (%) = F CH4 or CO,out/F CO2,in × 100% CO2 reaction rate (mmol gcat –1 h–1) = (F CO2,in – F CO2,out)/m cat where F is the molar flow rate, when WHSV = 60000 mL·gcat –1·h–1, F CO2, in is 490.6 mmol·gcat –1·h–1. Each test condition was tested more than twice. Stability tests were performed at 400 and 500 °C in same conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and surface properties of Mo2CTx and Ni/Mo2CTx The schematic sketch of the synthesis process for Mo2CT x MXene and Ni/Mo2CT x catalysts is reported in Fig. 1(a) . The synthesis followed an improved method of that reported by Wang et al. [29], where multilayered Mo2CT x was prepared by etching Mo2Ga2C with 10% HCl using a hydrothermal approach. As depicted in Fig. S1, Mo2Ga2C exhibits a thick layered structure, while multilayered Mo2CT x presents a thin, closely packed lamellar structure. In contrast, few-layered Mo2CT x shows a disordered porous morphology. The XRD patterns of Mo2Ga2C, Mo2CT x , and Ni/Mo2CT x are presented in Fig. 1(b). After etching, most characteristic peaks of Mo2Ga2C disappeared, and the (002) crystal plane, characteristic of layered materials, shifted from 2θ = 9.0° in Mo2Ga2C to 8.3°, indicating an increase in interlayer spacing from 0.89 to 1.06 nm. This shift confirms the successful synthesis of highly crystalline Mo2CT x MXene [30]. After nickel loading, only the characteristic diffraction peaks of Mo2CT x are observed in Ni/Mo2CT x . The (002) peak shifted slightly to 8.2°, corresponding to an interlayer spacing expansion to 1.07 nm, suggesting that Mo2CT x maintained its structural stability at 350 °C. XPS was utilised to analyse the elemental composition of the samples (Fig. 1(c)). The disappearance of the Ga 2p signal confirms the complete conversion of Mo2Ga2C to Mo2CT x . In the XPS survey spectra of both Mo2CT x and Ni/Mo2CT x , Cl signals were nearly undetectable, indicating minimal residual Cl on the Mo2CT x surface (Table S1). This result also suggests that the terminal groups on the Mo2CT x surface are predominantly —OH and —O [18,29]. The Raman spectra of the samples are presented in Fig. 1(e). For Mo2CT x , characteristic signals appeared at 143 and 258 cm–1, corresponding to the Ag vibrations of Mo atoms within the MXene lattice. Additional signals at 489 cm–1 were attributed to E2g vibrations of the terminal groups, while those at 669 cm–1 were associated with B2g vibrations of C atoms in the lattice [14,18,31]. The disappearance of the characteristic peaks of Mo2Ga2C and the emergence of those for Mo2CT x confirmed the successful synthesis of pure Mo2CT x . After Ni loading, no new Raman signals were observed because Ni was reduced to metallic nanoparticles during calcination, preventing the formation of detectable Raman signals from NiO. The morphology of Ni/Mo2CT x was analysed by SEM (Fig. S2). The results reveal that Ni/Mo2CT x maintains the characteristic geometric morphology of few-layer Mo2CT x . Additionally, EDS elemental mapping confirmed the uniform distribution of nickel across the Mo2CT x structure. The textural properties of the catalyst were further investigated through N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. S3). Both Mo2CT x and Ni/Mo2CT x exhibit Type IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops, indicative of slit-shaped pores [32]. The average pore diameters fall within the range of 10–100 nm (Table S2), primarily due to the layered stacking of MXene sheets. However, Ni loading results in a decrease in the specific surface area from 95 to 56 m2·g–1, which can be attributed to pore blockage by the deposited Ni particles. The structure of freshly synthesised Ni/Mo2CT x was characterised using HR-TEM. As shown in Fig. S4, Ni nanoparticles with an average diameter of 13.3 nm are uniformly distributed across the Mo2CT x surface. HR-TEM images revealed lattice fringes with spacings of 0.20 and 0.18 nm, corresponding to the (111) and (220) planes of metallic Ni, respectively. The crystal face angle between these planes was measured at 53°, consistent with theoretical values, confirming the presence of metallic Ni nanoparticles. Interestingly, calcination in an Ar atmosphere led to the direct reduction of Ni(CH3COO)2 to metallic Ni, bypassing the formation of NiO. This behaviour can be attributed to the strong reducing properties of MXene, which facilitate the fast reduction of NiO to metallic Ni. Despite a 10% Ni loading and an average particle size of 13.3 nm, no diffraction peaks corresponding to metallic Ni, NiO, or other Ni species were observed in the XRD patterns (Fig. 1(b)). Another special feature is that both Ni/Mo2CT x and reduced Ni/Mo2CT x exhibit no ferromagnetic properties. However, enhanced ferromagnetism was observed in samples with 20% Ni/Mo2CT x and 10% Ni/β-Mo2C, as shown in Fig. S5. 3.2 Catalytic CO2 hydrogenation The performances of the Ni/Mo2CT x catalyst in the thermal-catalysed hydrogenation of CO₂ are shown in Fig. 2 . The reaction was carried out at temperatures below 500 °C and ambient pressure to prevent the transformation of Mo2CT x into β-Mo2C. The products were analyzed using online gas chromatography after a 40-min stabilization period at each temperature. The products were CH4 and CO. No other products were detected. As shown in Fig. 2(a), the CO2 conversion of the Ni/Mo2CT x catalyst increased with temperature, reaching 43.5% at 500 °C. Initially, CO2 selectivity decreased with increasing temperature, reaching 21.6% at 400 °C and then reaching 66.5% at 500 °C. A second cycle test from 200 to 500 °C was made after the first scan to assess the stability of the catalyst. The CO2 conversion trend overlaps with that of the first cycle, but CO selectivity increased significantly, exceeding 93.0% across all temperatures. Notably, CO selectivity at 400 °C improved from 21.6% in the first cycle to 94.6% in the second cycle and further to 96.2% in the third cycle. The selectivity of CH4 and CO in CO2 hydrogenation is often influenced by thermodynamics. The lower temperatures (< 400 °C) favour methane formation, while higher temperatures (> 400 °C) favour CO production [33,34]. However, the observed changes in Ni/Mo2CT x selectivity do not align with thermodynamic predictions, suggesting a structural change of the Ni/Mo2CT x catalyst during the reaction. In contrast, the Ni/β-Mo2C catalyst exhibited a 25% decrease in CO2 conversion at 400 °C during the second cycle despite producing more CO (Fig. S6). Ni/SiO2 demonstrated excellent stability without changes in either CO2 conversion or CO selectivity over three cycles (Fig. S7). Consistent with previous reports [14], unsupported Mo2CT x also showed CO2 hydrogenation activity, achieving over 93% CO selectivity (Fig. S8). However, its CO2 conversion rate decreased by 29% at 400 °C in the second cycle. The reduced catalyst was pretreated for 2 h at 300, 400, and 500 °C under a H2/CO2 ratio of 4, followed by CO2 hydrogenation activity testing at 400 °C. As shown in Fig. 2(b), the catalysts treated at 300 and 400 °C exhibited CO selectivity of approximately 50%, while the sample treated at 500 °C for 2 h demonstrated a significant increase in CO selectivity to 92.7%. After treatment at 500 °C, the CO2 conversion rate decreased from 87.0 to 80.5 mmol·gcat –1·h–1. These results indicate that structural changes occurred in Ni/Mo2CT x during the 500 °C treatment. The catalyst’s stability was further evaluated through an isothermal test at 500 °C for over 20 h (Fig. 2(c)). The CO selectivity increased from 60.7% to 90.2% over the test duration, while the CO2 conversion exhibited a slight decline within the first 2 h, stabilising at 43.6%. In an isothermal test at 300 °C, the CO2 conversion increased modestly from 2.1% to 3.2%, and the CO selectivity rose from 79.6% to 82.8% (Fig. S9(a)). During a similar test at 400 °C, the CO2 conversion stabilised at 18.1%, with CO selectivity increasing significantly from 39.3% to 70.1% (Fig. S9(b)). These observations suggest that the catalyst maintains good structural stability at temperatures below 300 °C. However, at higher temperatures, gradual structural evolution occurs, leading to a shift in the primary product from CH4 to CO. The stability test results for Ni/Mo2CT x -T500 at 400 and 500 °C are shown in Fig. 2(d), further confirming these trends. In addition, an increase in the H2 reduction temperature results in higher CO selectivity. Specifically, under constant reaction conditions at 400 °C, both catalysts pre‐reduced at 400  and 500 °C exhibit a continuous increase in CO selectivity over time (Fig. S10). The stability of catalyst determines its application potential in industry. Stability tests at 400 and 500 °C for more than 100 h on stream indicate that the CO2 conversion for the Ni/Mo2CT x -T500 catalyst remains nearly unchanged. At the same time, the CO selectivity continued to increase with time on stream. At 100 h, the CO selectivity reached 97.4% at 400 °C. The above results show that Ni/Mo2CT x can maintain excellent stability at different temperatures, and the CO selectivity increases progressively with the time on stream. In contrast, as is shown in Fig. S11, in the stability test of Ni/β-Mo2C at 500 °C, the CO2 conversion rate continued to decrease, and the CO selectivity first decreased and then increased after 7 h, which also shows that Ni/MXene and Ni/β-Mo2C have different structural change behaviors. 3.3 Ni nanoparticles redispersion on Mo2CTx The catalytic reaction results suggest that the Ni/Mo2CT x catalyst undergoes structural changes during the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, leading to a gradual increase in CO selectivity over time. STEM and HR-TEM were used to study the structural changes of Ni/Mo2CT x before and after the reaction. Figs. 3(a) and 3(b) show the bright-field (BF)-STEM image and corresponding EELS mapping of Ni/Mo2CT x -R, indicating that darker regions correspond to Ni nanoparticles. Fig. 3(c) shows the EELS spectra of Mo and O elements on the support region, and the Mo-M and O-K edges were observed near 401 and 533 eV. The position and shape of the Mo-M edge are similar to those of β-Mo2C [35]. The Ni-L EELS signal at 849 eV in Fig. 3(d) indicates that the Ni nanoparticles are in a metallic state [36]. Fig. 3(e) presents a TEM image of Ni/Mo2CT x -R, similar to the fresh catalyst, with Ni nanoparticles of an average diameter of 12.9 nm evenly dispersed on the Mo2CT x surface. Figs. 3(h) and 3(i) display TEM images viewed from the Mo2CT x [001] and [100] axes, respectively, revealing spherical Ni nanoparticles anchored on the Mo2CT x surface. The FFT image in Fig. 3(h) also shows diffraction spots for Ni(111), Ni(220), and Mo2CT x (100) planes. Fig. 3(j) displays a HR-TEM image of Ni/Mo2CT x -T500, revealing Ni particles with an average diameter of 3.1 nm uniformly dispersed on the Mo2CT x surface. HR-TEM images viewed from the Mo2CT x [100] direction (Figs. 3(k) and (l)) confirm that Ni remains in a nanoparticle state instead of a monoatomic layer. The HR-TEM image viewed from the Mo2CT x [001] axis (Figs. 3(m) and 3(n)) confirms that the nanoparticles dispersed on the Mo2CT x surface are metallic Ni nanoparticles. XRD and Raman spectroscopy analyses were used to investigate this structural change further. Fig. 4(a) reports the XRD patterns of the catalysts, both reduced and after the catalytic tests. After reduction and reaction, only the characteristic diffraction peaks of Mo2CT x MXene were observed. No diffraction signals from β-Mo2C, MoO2, or other Ni species were detected, indicating that the Mo2CT x support maintained good stability without structural collapse during the reaction, even at the high temperature of 500 °C. The (002) diffraction peak of Mo2CT x after reduction shifted from a 2θ of 9.0° to 10.8°, suggesting a decrease in interlayer distance from 1.05 to 0.83 nm. It is worth noting that treatment of Mo2CT x in H2 at 500 °C can remove almost all the terminal groups; the (002) peak shifts to 11.5°, revealing that the interlayer spacing decreases to 0.78 nm [14,15]. This result indicates that part of the terminal groups of Ni/Mo2CT x are removed during the reaction, but not all of them [14]. As shown in Fig. 4(b), Raman spectra of the reduced and used catalysts also revealed characteristic signals of Mo2CT x MXene. Ni—Mo—O interface at 335 cm–1, possibly indicative of a Ni—Mo—O interface, appeared and strengthened with increasing reaction temperature [37]. The Ni—Mo—O species indicates that Ni and Mo atoms are directly bonded after some end groups are removed, breaking the isolation of the —O terminations. As the treatment temperature increases, the Ni—Mo—O signal intensity increases, indicating that more Ni—Mo—O species are generated at high temperatures. XPS was used to investigate the surface composition and electronic structure of the catalyst both before and after the reaction. As shown in Fig. 5(a) , the high-resolution Mo 3d XPS spectrum is fitted with three sets of peaks, including Mo—C (228.4 eV), O—Mo—C (229.6 eV), and MoO x (231.1 eV) [14,38]. The Mo—C species are related to the Mo atoms in Mo2CT x , where terminal groups are removed. The O—Mo—C species are attributed to Mo atoms connected with —O or —OH terminal groups. The MoO x belongs to MoO2 and MoO3–x , which form by the oxidation of Mo2CT x . Due to the complex composition and structure of MoO x , it has a larger FWHM [38]. As shown in Fig. 5(c), the content of Mo—C species in Ni/Mo2CT x -R and Ni/Mo2CT x -T400 is about 2 at%, but it increases to 7.1 at% in Ni/Mo2CT x -T500. This result indicates that under the CO2 hydrogenation reaction atmosphere at 500 °C, about 5% of the terminal groups are removed. The Ni 2p 3/2 spectrum is fitted with four sets of peaks: Ni0 (853.1 eV), NiO (856.4 eV), Ni(OH)2 (858.2 eV) and a satellite peak (Fig. 5(b)) [39]. Compared to the reduced catalyst, the Ni0 content slightly increased from 19.5 at% to 22.7 at% (Fig. 5(d)). After the reaction, the binding energy of Ni0 shifted slightly from 853.1 to 853.3 eV. Notably, in our previous studies, the binding energy of metallic Ni in Ni/SiO2 was located at 852.4 eV [39], indicating that more terminal groups are removed, leading to more electron density transferred from Ni to Mo2CT x . This result is similar to the results for Ni/α-Mo2C, where the Ni binding energy is located at 853.0–853.3 eV [40,41]. In addition, the O content in the sample after the reaction also decreased from 37.5 at% to 34.5 at% (Fig. S12). This result indicates that more —O/—OH terminal groups are removed from Ni/Mo2CT x -T500, and more negative charge is transferred from Ni to Mo2CT x . H2-TPR was used to examine the reduction behaviour of the Ni/Mo2CT x catalyst in a hydrogen atmosphere. As illustrated in Fig. S13, two reduction peaks were observed at 373 and 687 °C, corresponding to the partial and complete removal of terminal groups, respectively. According to XRD test results, partial removal of the terminal groups does not lead to the conversion of Mo2CT x into β-Mo2C (Fig. 4(a)). However, removing more terminal groups may result in the formation of β-Mo2C. As shown in Fig. S14, reduction at 600°C of Ni/Mo2CT x resulted in the aggregation of β-Mo2C and Ni nanoparticles. 3.4 CO2 hydrogenation mechanisms The Ni-catalysed hydrogenation of CO2 is a structure-sensitive reaction [42,43]. Small Ni nanoparticles have lower adsorption strength for formate and CO, mainly generating CO through the direct dissociation pathway of CO2. CO2 primarily follows the formate pathway to produce methane in large Ni nanoparticles. Fig. S15 show the Arrhenius plots for CO2 conversion and the formation of CH4 and CO. Since the performance of the reduced catalyst changes dramatically during the reaction, Ni/Mo2CT x -T400 is used as a sample representing a high CH4 selectivity catalyst. Compared to Ni/Mo2CT x -T400, the activation energy of Ni/Mo2CT x -T500 decreased from 68.6 to 56.5 kJ·mol–1, which correlates with the slight increase in CO2 conversion rate at the beginning of the reaction. After treatment at 500 °C, the activation energy for CH4 formation decreased from 98.3 to 69.7 kJ·mol–1, while the activation energy for CO formation showed no significant change. These results suggest that methanation follows a different reaction pathway on Ni/Mo2CT x -T400 and Ni/Mo2CT x -T500, while the RWGS underwent a similar reaction pathway. The CO2 reaction order test revealed that the reaction orders for Ni/Mo2CT x -T400 and Ni/Mo2CT x -T500 were 0.47 and 0.51, respectively. This increase in the reaction order suggests that the adsorption intensity of CO2 on the catalyst decreased after use at 500 °C (Fig. S16(a)). Similarly, the H2 reaction orders increased significantly from 0.37 (Ni/Mo2CT x -T400) to 0.43 (Ni/Mo2CT x -T500), indicating a reduction in hydrogen adsorption strength on the catalyst treated at 500 °C (Fig. S16(b)). Previous studies have demonstrated that the hydrogenation of CO2 to CO and CH4 on Ni predominantly follows three reaction pathways: (1) the carbide pathway, where CO2 dissociates into CO, which is subsequently hydrogenated to form CH4; (2) the formate pathway, where CO2 undergoes a reaction from carbonate to formate; and (3) the carboxyl pathway involving the transformation of CO2 through carbonate to carboxyl [1, 6]. In-situ DRIFTS was used to investigate the reaction mechanisms underlying the selective shift in CO2 hydrogenation. As shown in Fig. S17, upon introducing CO2 + H2 at 50 °C, bands in 2143 cm–1 and near 3600 cm–1 appeared, corresponding to gas phase CO and hydroxyl (—OH) groups, respectively [44]. CO originates from the dissociation of CO2 into CO* on the catalyst surface, followed by desorption to form gas phase CO. CO only appears at the beginning of the reaction and quickly disappears. A similar phenomenon was observed when only CO2 is fed (Fig. S18). Upon introducing CO2, gas phase CO quickly formed and then disappeared, while adsorbed CO* species were not detected. The interpretation is that the O* species (deriving from the dissociation of CO2) react with the —O terminal group or oxidises the Ni NPs, thus resulting in a low intensity of the CO chemisorbed signal [45]. This result is further supported by the absence of CO2 and CO desorption signals in CO2-TPD and CO-TPD (Fig. S19). CO2 dissociates to CO, which desorbs at room temperature because CO is difficult to adsorb onto the oxidized catalyst. In the CO2 + H2 atmosphere, the relevant absorption bands in the in-situ DRIFTS are mainly in the 1000–2200 cm–1 region. Under CO2 hydrogenation conditions, absorbed intermediates, including carboxyl (1660–1800 cm–1) [46,47], formate (1558 and 1339 cm–1) [48–50], bidentate carbonate (1510 and 1303 cm–1) [48,50] as well as gas phase CO (2143 cm–1) [51] and CH4 (3014 cm–1) [6] were observed. As the temperature increased to 200 °C, stronger formate, carboxyl and bidentate carbonate (b-CO3*) bands appeared, along with continuous gaseous CO and CH4 (Figs. 6(a) and S20), indicating that CO2 reacts with surface hydroxyl groups to form b-CO3*, which then converts into carboxyl and formate intermidiates. The Carbonyl species mainly decompose into CO and OH*. The formate can be decomposed as CO or hydrogenation to CH4 [2]. Furthermore, the carbonyl and formate species weakened rapidly after the withdrawal of CO2 + H2 (Fig. S21). This result demonstrates that the Ni/Mo2CT x -R catalyst follows the carboxyl and formate pathway. Fig. 6(b) shows the in-situ DRIFTS spectra of Ni/Mo2CT x -T500 in CO2 + H2. Compared to the sample before treatment, Ni/Mo2CT x -T500 has a weaker formate and carboxyl band intensity (Figs. 6(c) and (d)). This result indicates that on Ni/Mo2CT x -T500, the formate pathway is less relevant, while the bidentate carbonate adsorbed on the catalyst has difficulty being hydrogenated to form formate. Based on the in-situ DRIFTS experiments, CO2 hydrogenation on Ni/Mo2CT x -R and Ni/Mo2CT x -T500 follows the CO2 direct dissociation, carboxyl and formate pathways with a fewer carboxyl and formate intermediate observed on Ni/Mo2CT x -T500. However, the competitive relationship between the formate pathway and CO2 direct dissociation pathways cannot be clearly discriminated. Therefore, D2-KIE experiments and hydrogen spillover experiments for CO2 and CO hydrogenation were used to analyse the activation sites of H2 and CO2. Fig. 7 shows the D2-KIE experiments in CO2 and CO hydrogenation reactions for Ni/Mo2CT x -R and Ni/Mo2CT x -T500. The k H2/k D2 < 1 in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction indicates the reverse kinetic isotope effect (R-KIE). It can be attributed to an H-containing intermediate formed in the rate-determining step of CO2 hydrogenation (Fig. 7(c)) [39]. Combined with the in-situ DRIFTS data, the origin of R-KIE in CO2 hydrogenation is due to the formate pathway. Meanwhile, the higher k H2/k D2 ratio (0.8 vs. 0.77) indicates a reduced proportion of the formate and carboxyl pathways. Conversely, a normal KIE effect occurs in the CO hydrogenation reaction (Fig. 7(b)), suggesting different rate-determining steps between CO2 hydrogenation and CO hydrogenation, e.g., the rate-determining step of the CO2 hydrogenation occurs at the stage of CO2 hydrogenation to CO. Additionally, it was noted that the rates of CO hydrogenation for Ni/Mo2CT x -R and Ni/Mo2CT x -T500 decreased to 14% and 10% of the rates of CO2 hydrogenation, respectively (Figs. S22 and S23). This result differs from our previous data, showing a higher rate of CO to CO2 hydrogenation on Ni/mSiO2 [39]. This also indicates that the path of methane production from CO hydrogenation is inhibited in the Ni/Mo2CT x catalyst. This suggests that the methane produced in CO2 hydrogenation mainly comes from the formate pathway rather. As illustrated in Fig. 7(d), the partial removal of the terminal groups and fragmentation of Ni nanoparticles cause a CO2 hydrogenation shift from CH4 to CO. Initially, under CO2 hydrogenation conditions, H2 dissociates on the Ni nanoparticles generating hydrogen spillover species which diffuse over the Mo2CT x surface and react with —O and —OH terminal groups to generate water. Ni NPs migrate to the exposed Mo atomic surfaces to form small particles of about 3.1 nm. The observation that WO3 turns blue in H2, as shown in Fig. S24, confirms the hydrogen spillover of Mo2CT x . On larger Ni particles, CO2 is primarily converted to CH4 via the formate pathways. In contrast, on smaller Ni particles and exposed Mo surfaces, CO2 follows the carbide pathway, leading to CO formation. In this pathway, CO2 first dissociates on Mo2CT x , generating CO and surface oxygen species (O* or —O groups). Subsequently, H2 dissociates on Ni nanoparticles, and the resulting hydrogen atoms spill over onto the Mo2CT x surface. The surface oxygen species then react with the spilled hydrogen (H*) species, forming H2O and regenerating active Mo sites, thereby sustaining the catalytic cycle. The smaller Ni particles also resulted in a decrease in the CO2 conversion rate. Simultaneously, the Mo surfaces become occupied by —O terminal groups and active hydrogen from the Ni NPs can re-clear these groups, closing the catalytic cycle. 4 Conclusions CO2 hydrogenation catalysts based on Ni NPs supported on Mo2CT x MXene were successfully synthesised. Their structural in-situ changes during the reaction were systematically investigated. The initial Ni/Mo2CT x -R catalyst exhibited a unique CO selectivity profile, where an initial decrease was followed by an increase, achieving a minimum CO selectivity of 21.3%. During consecutive reaction cycles, the catalyst showed a CO selectivity exceeding 93% at all temperatures, while CO2 conversion remained nearly unchanged in the series of reaction cycles. This behaviour can be attributed to the removal of approximately 7% of surface end groups under reaction conditions, facilitating direct interaction between Ni and Mo atoms rather than indirect interaction via —O terminal groups. This direct Ni—Mo interaction strengthens the metal-support interaction, enabling more efficient charge transfer from Ni to Mo2CT x . Consequently, Ni particles disperse and reduce in size from an average size of 12.9 to 3.1 nm. The in-situ transformation effectively inhibits formate formation, suppressing the formate and coarboxyl pathway and enhancing the carbide pathway. These structural and mechanistic changes result in a decreased rate of CH4 production for the catalyst. This study offers a novel strategy for designing high-performance catalysts using MXene as support and deepens our understanding of metal-carbide interactions. coredata.dc:description: The catalyst’s structural dynamics under reaction conditions critically determine their performance. We proved this indication by studying Ni nanoparticles supported on Mo2CT x MXene, where the average size during CO2 hydrogenation changed from 12.9 to 3.1 nm. A parallel increase of CO selectivity from 21.1% to 92.6% at 400 °C was observed, while the CO2 conversion rate remained at about 84.0 mmol·gcat –1·h–1. This transformation involved partial removal of Mo2CT x terminal groups, allowing direct interaction between Ni and Mo atoms instead of indirect coupling through -O terminations. The shift from a Ni-O-Mo to a Ni-Mo interaction enhanced electron transfer from Ni to Mo2CT x , strengthening the metal-support interaction and driving Ni nanoparticle dispersion. In-situ mechanistic analysis and kinetic isotope studies revealed that Ni dispersion suppresses the formate and carboxyl pathway, promotes direct CO2 dissociation, and inhibits CO hydrogenation, shifting the primary product from CH4 to CO. These findings provide a strategy for designing highly selective and stable MXene-based catalysts through engineered metal-support interactions.
